metadata.title: isofit
metadata.description:
New updates that have a variety of quality of life improvements and bug fixes.

What's Changed

  • Clean up and simplification of radiative transfer module by @unbohn in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/524
  • basic tanager syntax by @pgbrodrick in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/634
  • tanager patches by @pgbrodrick in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/643
  • Relax Dependencies by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/640
  • Merge dev for release by @pgbrodrick in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/644
  • Isoplots Integration by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/615
  • Generate config and exit: apply_oe by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/647
  • Added check in calc_rdn for s_alb = 0 by @evan-greenbrg in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/645
  • Downloaders Bugfixes by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/648
  • LUT Compression, rebased by @pgbrodrick in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/651

Full Changelog: https://github.com/isofit/isofit/compare/v3.3.6...v3.4.1

metadata.title: A behavioral setup for capturing fine grained coordinated movements of zebrafish larvae
metadata.description:
Animals use their whole body to navigate their environment and solve tasks. Identification of common dynamics of body parts using quantitative methods is key to study underlying motor system organization. Zebrafish (Danio rerio) need to coordinate tail and pectoral fin movements and can serve as a model organism for the study of locomotion generation. Behavioral tracking of larval zebrafish has usually restricted itself either to track only the position and tail movements of freely swimming zebrafish larvae, or to track fine movements of body parts in immobilized fish. This precludes studies that investigate coordination or postural control. 

To study full body coordination, we built a setup that allows us to track freely swimming larval zebrafish, while acquiring high resolution images of their whole body. This enables tracking of both tail and fins using DeepLabCut with additional segmentation and classification of the tail using the Megabouts algorithm. First, we describe stereotypical fin dynamics at bout onset which show differences between modes of movements as forward swims and turns. Thereafter we show that fin dynamics can be embedded on a low dimensional manifold with axes corresponding to amplitude, vigor and frequency. Based on this embedding, fin dynamics show a degree of stereotypy with associated tail classification. Lastly, we show that a model that captures the latent dynamics underlying tail movement generation, developed using ILQR-VAE, is able to predict fin dynamics, hinting towards a coupled control mechanism. Overall, this represents an important step towards building a comprehensive dictionary of larval zebrafish locomotion that will enable better study of motion generation and coordination.

data.title: A behavioral setup for capturing fine grained coordinated movements of zebrafish larvae

metadata.title: Evolution of BBL in Instructional Design in Higher Education: Scoping review (2013-2024)
metadata.description: This study aims to analyze the evolution of brain-based learning and its connection to instructional design in global higher education, utilizing a bibliometric analysis of publications in the Scopus and Web of Science databases from January 2013 to March 2024. The examination of the texts included VOSviewer, Excel, and Visme software.  The review recorded the development and geographical dispersion of the literature, while also delineating the ideological framework of BBL and instructional design in higher education.
metadata.method:
Explanation of existing data

The timeframe selected for this evaluation is the past decade, which spans from January 2013 to March 2024, comprising a decade and three months. Scopus and Web of Science (WOS) were the databases employed, as they are the most frequently employed for bibliometric analysis (Pranckutė, 2021). The review protocol was designed based on the type of study. The methodology and guidelines recommended by the Joanna Briggs Institute (Peters et al., 2020) as cited in Medina-Córdoba et al. (2023) were followed, as well as the PRISMA reporting guidelines "Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR)" (Tricco et al., 2018 cited by Medina-Córdoba et al. 2023).

 

Data collection procedures

Source identification for this study will be conducted according to the Preferred Reporting Criteria for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, which detail procedures for identifying papers for inclusion in systematic analyses of research reviews (Page et al., 2021). The review will focus on articles published in journals indexed in Scopus and Web of Science (WOS) in both English and Spanish. Conference papers, conference proceedings, books and book chapters will be excluded, since articles from peer-reviewed journals go through a more rigorous publication process and are considered more reliable in the academic field (Hallinger, 2020).

 

Stopping rule

The size of the articles will be controlled by the number of articles that the time frame chosen for this scoping review yields, which covers the last ten years (January 2013 to March 2024 - one decade and 3 months) in the databases that will be used, Scopus and Web of Science (WOS).

data.title: Evolution of BBL in Instructional Design in Higher Education: Scoping review (2013-2024)

metadata.title: D3.3 - Transferring Innovation Best Practices
metadata.description:
The digiNEB.eu project successfully created a platform for transferring innovation best practices in support of the New European Bauhaus (NEB) initiative. Over its duration, the project showed that digital technologies can support the transition towards sustainable, inclusive, and aesthetically enriched living spaces, aligning with the European Green Deal's ambitions. Through a combination of mapping, stakeholder engagement, capacity-building, and knowledge dissemination, digiNEB.eu has delivered concrete results that have an impact across Europe. The key achievements of digiNEB are:

Mapping and Showcasing Digital Solutions and Projects

digiNEB.eu successfully mapped NEB-related projects and curated a Digital Toolkit comprising innovative digital solutions aligning with the NEB values. These tools and services provide stakeholders with practical, accessible resources to address NEB challenges. By combining innovations in the built environment into a comprehensive online toolkit of tools, projects and actors, digiNEB.eu connected research outcomes and real-world applications, empowering users to implement solutions that enhance sustainability, inclusivity, and aesthetic quality in European living environments.

Building a Pan-European Network

The project cultivated a vibrant, cross-disciplinary community of stakeholders, representing a diverse array of actors, including architects, designers, SMEs, policymakers, and civil society organisations.

This network has been instrumental in promoting the best practices identified by the project. Through the Technical Working Groups (TWGs) and the External Advisory Group (EAG), digiNEB.eu fostered meaningful collaboration and knowledge-sharing across sectors and guided the development of strategies for transferring innovative solutions to diverse contexts.

Capacity Building and Knowledge Transfer

digiNEB.eu successfully conducted 16 multi-stakeholder workshops and 6 webinars, bringing together professionals, innovators, educators and policy actors to exchange knowledge and explore best practices. These events facilitated learning, networking and the transfer of innovation across the NEB community. To facilitate knowledge transfer, digiNEB-eu set up an e-learning catalogue of online courses aligning with the NEB values. digiNEB cooperates with the development of an eLearning platform feeding the NEBA project facilitating the platform’s long-term sustainability. In this way, digiNEB leverages the knowledge of the digital ecosystem, the pan-European network and knowledge building towards creating a platform for capacity building.

Showcasing Best Practices

The project culminated in the open-access publication of Deliverable 3.3, a comprehensive resource that captures the transfer of innovation best practices throughout the project. This publication showcases the activities performed to strengthen the pan-European capacity building connecting regions, communities and actors through a multi-layered multi-stakeholder approach. These activities focused on collectively sharing innovations applied to real-world NEB challenges, offering replicable solutions for stakeholders across Europe. Events featured in the publication highlight concrete examples of innovative projects, tools and actors that have shown best practices in line with the NEB values.

Conclusion

The digiNEB.eu project has delivered significant and lasting contributions in transferring innovation best practices across Europe. By fostering a multi-layered, multi-stakeholder collaborative and crossdisciplinary network and providing access to tools, projects and actors that are successfully paving the way, digiNEB.eu has empowered stakeholders to actively engage with the NEB community. The project's outputs, from the Digital Toolkit, the online platform or the policy recommendations, ensure that digital innovation will continue to drive the transformation of European living spaces, making them more sustainable, inclusive, and beautiful for generations to come.

grants.title: Digital ecosystem for the New European Bauhaus initiative (DigiNEB)

metadata.title: Eugenia velutifolia Mazine & Sobral 2019, sp. nov.
metadata.description:
Eugenia velutifolia Mazine & Sobral, sp. nov.

Type:— BRAZIL. São Paulo: Itu, Área de Proteção Ambiental, Cerrado, 16 July 1987, W.S. Souza & R.M. Britez 25249 (holotype UEC!). Figures 1, 2 and 3

Diagnosis: —This species is morphologically related to Eugenia bimarginata De Candolle (1828: 271) from which it is kept apart by its velutinous indumentum on leaves and twigs (versus glabrous or rarely puberulent leaves, and glabrous twigs), leaf blade with undulate margin (vs. revolute but not undulate margin) and larger sepals, 2–3 mm (vs. sepals 1–2 mm). It also resembles Eugenia livida O. Berg (1859: 584), but it is distinguished from it by the velutinous indumentum with brown trichomes on both sides of leaf blade and twigs (vs. leaf blade glabrescent adaxially and pubescent-velutinous abaxially, twigs glabrescent, with yellow-opaque trichomes), leaf blade with undulate margin (vs. revolute but not undulate margin), midvein slightly sulcate, plane to slightly prominent adaxially (vs. biconvex), and sepals 2–3 mm (vs. sepals 1–1.5 mm).

Shrub 0.6–1.3 m tall. Twigs terete to applanate, the distal internodes 1.5–2.5 cm, velutinous. Leaves ovate or wide ovate, rare elliptic, 5–9 × 2.7–5.5 cm; translucent punctuations evident on both surfaces, but more pronounced on the adaxial surface, 6–10 dots/mm²; velutinous on both surfaces, brown and erect trichomes; apex acute to obtuse; base rounded to cordate; midvein slightly sulcate, plane to slightly prominent on adaxial surface and prominent on abaxial surface; lateral veins 7–11 at each side; marginal vein 1–3.5 mm from the margin; the margin itself revolute with yellow thickening and undulate; petiole 1–2 mm, velutinous. Inflorescences racemiform with a reduced axis (ca. 1.5 mm), mainly axillary, with 4–8 flowers, glabrous. Floral buds globose, 3–4 mm diameter; pedicels 5–10 mm, glabrous; bracteoles ovate to elliptic, ca. 1 mm, ciliate, brown trichomes, persistent at anthesis; hypanthium 2–3 mm, glabrous; sepals four, ovate, 2–3 × 2–3 mm, ciliate; petals four, white, apex acute to round, 4–7 × 3–4 mm, glabrous, translucent punctuations evident; stamens more than 30, the filaments 5–7 mm, the anthers oblong-elliptical; style 5–7 mm long, glabrous; ovary with two locules and 7–9 ovules per locule. Fruits not seen.

Distribution, habitat, and phenology: —As far as we know there are only six collections of Eugenia velutifolia from two localities, in the municipalities of Itu and Salto de Pirapora, São Paulo state, southeastern Brazil (Figure 3). It occurs at severely fragmented grassland areas in Cerrado vegetation, between 600–700 m elev. The species was collected with flowers in May and July.

Conservation: — Eugenia velutifolia has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 18.575 km ². São Paulo’s Cerrado areas are severely fragmented, especially those that aren’t protected, and the species could be in a significant risk to be extinct due to the continuous decline in habitat quality caused by activities such as cattle farming, mineral extraction, and the increasing of real estate market. Considering its geographic range, E. velutifolia could be evaluated as Critically Endangered, according to IUCN Red List Criteria B1ab (i, iii).

Etymology: —The specific epithet refers to the velutinous indumentum on the leaf blade.

Affinities: —Considering the sections of Eugenia proposed by Mazine et al. (2016), Eugenia velutifolia might be assigned to Eugenia sect. Umbellatae O. Berg (1855 –1856: 204), due to its fasciculate inflorescences and flowers with pedicels at least four times longer than internodes of the inflorescence axis. For the section, this species is morphologically related with Eugenia bimarginata, E. livida and E. suberosa Cambessèdes (1833: 364), all shrubs occurring in Brazilian Cerrado vegetation. Although, Eugenia velutifolia can easily be kept apart from them by the velutinous indumentum with brown trichomes on both sides of the leaf blade and twigs, the midvein not biconvex, leaves with undulate margins, and also by its larger sepals (Table 1).

The contrasting characters among E. velutifolia to E. bimarginata and E. livida can be seen in the diagnosis. Eugenia velutifolia can be kept apart from E. suberosa also by the leaf blade with rounded to cordate base (vs. leaf blade with acute to obtuse base in E. suberosa). A summary of morphological features that characterize these four species is presented in Table 1.

Paratypes: — BRAZIL. São Paulo: Itu, Fazenda São Miguel, Campo Cerrado, 10 July 2007, R. M. Britez 1718 (MBM!); Propriedade rural ao lado da Fazenda São Miguel, -23.3891, -47.3049, 11 May 2018, K.S. Valdemarin & G.Z. Sant’ana 1134, 1135 (ESA!, SORO!); Ibid., -23.3896, -47.3055, G.Z. Sant’ana & K.S. Vademarin 34 (ESA!, SORO!). Salto de Pirapora, remanescente de Cerrado (fitofisionomia aberta), área de extração de areia, -23.6659, -47.6191, 23 May 2018, P.H. Gaem 150 (SORO!).

metadata.title: Development of Controlled Release Microspheres of amoxicillin by using Natural Gums
metadata.description: The present investigation aimed to formulate and evaluate in vitro performances of controlled release amoxicillin microspheres for the potential application in the treatment of gastric and duodenal ulcers, which were associated with Helicobacter pylori.  Method: Amoxicillin control release microspheres containing as guar gum and xanthan gum as control release polymer were prepared by an external ionotropic gelation method using sodium alginate and calcium chloride. The prepared microspheres were evaluated for their micromeritic properties, drug content and encapsulation efficiency and characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, differential scanning calorimetry, X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy. The in vitro release studies were performed by buffer change method using pH 1.2 buffer and pH 6.8 phosphate buffer. Results: The preliminary trials results indicate that quantity of gelling agent, drug-to-polymers ratio, time for stirring and speed of rotation has impact on the characteristics of microspheres. The prepared microspheres were half white, free flowing, spherical in shape with mean particle size in the range of 450 to 779 µm. The drug-loaded microspheres showed 60.42-89.23% of entrapment and in vitro drug release was extended up to 12 hr releasing 18.9 –93.86 % of the total drug from the microspheres. The optimized formulation batch exhibited high drug entrapment efficiency of 83%, the particle size was 450 µm and a controlled drug release was observed for more than 12 hr. The infrared spectra showed stable character of amoxicillin in the drug-loaded microspheres and revealed the absence of drug-polymer interactions. The morphological characteristics of the microspheres were studied under a scanning electron microscopy revealed that the microspheres were spherical and porous in nature. In vitro release studies showed that amoxicillin released bit slightly faster in pH 1.2 gastric fluid than in pH 7.8 phosphate buffer. The release kinetics was achieved with Koresmeyer-Peppas plot followed by zero order with Fickian diffusion mechanism. Conclusions: The prolonged gastrointestinal residence time and enhanced amoxicillin stability resulting from the amoxicillin microspheres might make a contribution to H. pylori complete eradication

creators.name: Afreen Khan*, Arpita Verma, Ashutosh Rajak, Dhawal Pal, Rajat Pawar

keywords: Amoxicillin, microspheres, guar gum, xanthan gum

data.title: Development of Controlled Release Microspheres of amoxicillin by using Natural Gums

metadata.title: Enabling Navigation and Mission-based Control on a Low-cost Unitree Go1 Air Quadrupedal Robot
metadata.description: An open source firmware for the CYW943907AEVAL1F kit that implements wired and wireless interfaces between the Unitree Go1 robot and the ArduPilot controller. The firmware complements the research paper "Enabling Navigation and Mission-based Control on a Low-cost Unitree Go1 Air Quadrupedal Robot".

data.title: Enabling Navigation and Mission-based Control on a Low-cost Unitree Go1 Air Quadrupedal Robot

metadata.title: mFD: an R package to compute and illustrate the multiple facets of functional diversity
metadata.description: Functional diversity (FD), the diversity of organism attributes that relates to their interactions with the abiotic and biotic environment, has been increasingly used for the last two decades in ecology, biogeography and conservation. Yet, FD has many facets and their estimations are not standardized nor embedded in a single tool. mFD (multifaceted functional diversity) is an R package that uses matrices of species assemblages and species trait values as building blocks to compute most FD indices. mFD is firstly based on two functions allowing the user to summarize trait and assemblage data. Then it calculates trait-based distances between species pairs, informs the user whether species have to be clustered into functional entities and finally computes multidimensional functional space. To let the user choose the most appropriate functional space for computing multidimensional functional diversity indices, two mFD functions allow assessing and illustrating the quality of each functional space. Next, mFD provides 6 core functions to calculate 16 existing FD indices based on trait-based distances, functional entities or species position in a functional space. The mFD package also provides graphical functions based on the ggplot library to illustrate FD values through customizable and high-resolution plots of species distribution among functional entities or in a multidimensional space. All functions include internal validation processes to check for errors in data formatting which return detailed error messages. To facilitate the use of mFD framework, we built an associated website hosting five tutorials illustrating the use of all the functions step by step.
